Our group booked junior suite and a one bedroom suite and were very pleased. The hotel has recently upgraded floors on Club levels that are more up to date. The rooms we had (911, 915, 917, 918) were all clean, luxurious, comfortable although were a bit dated. Huge marble bathrooms. Spacious dressing areas and small kitchenettes. The restaurants were great and staff quite accomodating. Special rates made this an amazing buy for this 5 star property.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Scotus
Reviews.Content: After reading some of the recent reviews, I was nervous about my stay at the Windsor Court. My group stayed at the hotel four nights, and everyone was pleased with the hotel and the service. First, several reviews have commented that the rooms are in bad shape. I had a chance to take a look at four rooms, and all were in very good to excellent condition. The rooms had some minor wallpaper and carpet issues, but nothing to detract from the room or our stay. I had a junior suite, with a very nice sitting area, two balconies, wet bar, and an enormous dressing area and bathroom. All the furniture was in very good shape. The bed was very comfortable. Also, there is a safe in the room for guest use. Second, the service was very good, with the exception of one front desk worker who seemed a little snooty. However, everyone else was friendly and helpful. Third, the common areas are in great shape, including the lobby and the pool area. Fourth, the hotel offers several free amenities not offered by most high end hotels. Amazingly, Internet access is free. Also, both the local and national papers are delivered to your room in the morning. Next, although there is no coffee maker in the room, free coffee and tea are available in the lobby. We paid $189 a night for the junior suite on the Papa Noel Rate, I can honestly say that this one of the best deals I have ever gotten on a hotel room.

Reviews.Title: “Faded Grande Dame”
Reviews.Author: ncinaz
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Windsor Court for three nights in late November/early December and found a once-great hotel now badly faded. The televisions are from the 1980s, wallpaper is peeling, furniture is laughably stained, and the notepads in the room had writing on every page. Service remains a high point, although one of the concierges couldn't have been less knowledgeable or helpful. We expected service issues but were pleasantly surprised by how outgoing and friendly most of the staff were. The shocker was how ancient the rooms looked. Our couches and chairs were an embarrassment. Apparently the club floor rooms have been redone but I didn't hear about any upgrading plans for the rest of the place. We tried to upgrade to the club floors but a corporate group had booked all of them. Hopefully one of these days the owners will wake up and return the place to its former splendor.

Reviews.Title: “Nice visit, but lock up your valuables!!!”
Reviews.Author: wingsr1
Reviews.Content: I went as a part of "Girls Weekend Out" with two other ladies. We had a great time in the city and would like to say that New Orleans is back and welcoming to all visitors. The hotel is right across from Harrah's and we had a great time at the casino after dinner each night we were there. The location was convenient for both the casino and the French Market on Saturday morning. The Windsor Court Grill was a great dining experience even though there were issues with the wine selection. Picked two and they didn't have either, but they did make up for it with the bill. Richard was our waiter and I can highly recommend asking for him. He was wonderful and made our experience excellent and far better than the next evening at Emeril's. Issues: We arrived after dark and the hotel was a bit difficult to find. There aren't any visible signs, technically they are "secluded" but when you aren't familiar with the city it can be a tough place to locate. Probably drove by it 3 times before stopping to ask two cops, but of course we were sitting directly outside the hotel!!! Bet they thought we had started celebrating early. On Saturday we were in a hurry to go to a wedding and I made the mistake of not putting my jewelry in the safe. My fault, but didn't expect the housekeeping staff to go through my suitcase to find it. This is a place where doors are closed when the staff is cleaning and they have the time to go through your stuff so beware. Like I said, my fault, but shouldn't have to worry about the staff at a hotel like this. Overall we enjoyed the experience and I would stay there again, but would ensure that I either don't leave anything of value or would use the safe religiously.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic property - Windsor Court!”
Reviews.Author: pixel_93
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend the Windsor Court in New Orleans. Everything about it is top notch. Friendly staff, beautifully decorated lobby and absolutely charming decor in the guest rooms. Everything looks brand new, but has the boutique quality so it doesn't feel like a cookie cutter hotel. The bathrooms are huge and the amenities are very nice. Our room was extremely quiet which was a pleasant surprise. Most hotels have noise coming from all directions. We didn't hear a sound. They also serve high tea in the afternoons. Be sure to experience that. We have stayed in many high-end properties all over the U.S. and would rate the Windsor Court near the top when comparing price and quality. One bonus about Windsor Court - Harrah's Casino is right across the street and so are the Shops at Canal Place, an upscale mall. The French Quarter is also just a short walk away.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced/not good value”
Reviews.Author: Barb3456
Reviews.Content: Egads, I cannot believe this is an Am Ex Black Card property. What a dump. This is the first hotel ever I stayed in where the bathroom was missing faucet handles (I kid you not) and the first hotel in this price range where the blanket had fresh mystery stains. We wrote a note to the manager. I would like to say he or she was concerned. He or she may have been but we can't be sure since we never heard back. This prompted a second note to the manager (now more of a curiosity to see if anyone cared) to ask about missing soap, soap dishes and toiletries. At this price range, you'd think we could get a bar of soap! Not a word. At least they are consistent. Room service breakfast (rolls and coffee) 45 minutes or more. We are coming back to New Orleans in a month to volunteer for Habitat. We are trying the Loews across the street. I hear they have soap. And at these prices the Windsor should.

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel in the Country”
Reviews.Author: sf24
Reviews.Content: This is my favorite hotel in the country. In addition to wonderful facilities, the people are wonderful in every respect. It is in the best location in New Orleans no matter what your plans are.

Reviews.Title: “"Very Nice, But Not Extraordinary"”
Reviews.Author: scottishlad
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent a three day weekend in New Orleans and had the opportunity to stay at the Windsor Court. My sense is New Orleans books few conventions during September because of hurricanes, so we got a very nice price at this celebrated hotel. Our first visit. A nice welcome upon checking in and an upgrade to a small suite! Wonderful. Avoided the hotel parking fee of $30+ a day by parking one block away in an open air lot on Poydras Street. Later in the day, I told the front desk that the air conditioning was not working well in the bedroom and they agreed to fix it while we were out for dinner. Upon returning, I noticed that the thermostat was turned down, but really no solution to this problem during the entire weekend. The next morning, it was very nice to sit in the court area of the lobby with their complimentary coffee. And I was able to choose from five morning newspapers on their rack. (Sipping my coffee and reading the Financial Times in the Windsor Court that morning made me think that I actually had money! And then I came to.) A couple of other negatives. The toliet did not work well, and generally required two/three flushes. The television is in a box and can be rotated for viewing from bedroom or living room, but it is clunky and needs to be replaced by a flat TV. Another reviewer talked about the lack of ice on each floor and yes, it was irritating. I had expected to pay for Internet, but it was complimentary. A terrific gin and tonic in the Polo Bar. The Windsor Court is in a very good location. Next September, check the prices at this hotel. My price was about 70% less than their normal rate. Classy place.

Reviews.Title: “What a way to celebrate!”
Reviews.Author: jdblakesle
Reviews.Content: Our weekend in New Orleans was perfected by our stay at Windsor Court. I had made the reservations online at the hotel's website, noting an offer for a suite and breakfast for $179 nightly. We were whisked away to a beautiful suite on the 12th floor, with a spectacular view of the river. Later, the hotel sent up a bottle of champagne, in honor of my hubby's birthday. We had drinks both nights in the Polo Lounge, and breakfast each morning in the N. O. Grill, both areas are lavish and elegant. The staff could not have been more pleasant and helpful, eager to make our stay wonderful in every way. This is one fancy but not stuffy hotel...don't miss an opportunity to stay in luxury near the French Quarter!

Reviews.Title: “Awesome!! Best ever!!”
Reviews.Author: kimblackwood
Reviews.Content: This was the best experience we have ever had in ANY hotel. The customer service was exceptional - never experienced any better. Hotel is GORGEOUS & conveniently located. We had a great experience. You cannot go wrong if you stay here!!!!

Reviews.Title: “AVOID!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! One of the worst pretentious hotel worldwide”
Reviews.Author: blafwasa
Reviews.Content: With the exception of few paintings, this is a complete nightmare. The best would be to fire the whole staff (but the barman) and to destroy the building to do something else. First, location has no interest: avoid the area and go directly to the French quarter. This part of the city does have any assets. Then, arrival is a nightmare with an unfriendly bellstaff who prefer talking with friends than taking care of the arriving guests. By the way, have a look on your luggage as soft ones are systematically put down heavy hard ones! Lobby is an ugly mixture of false Louis XIV and English manor: pretentious, old-fashioned and do not go to details as everything is bad modern industrialized copies. At the reception, no way to get your room on time: waiting 5 hours in the afternoon does not look like a problem! And do not wait for any solution or proposition such as a drink or anything else! The room: not that small and not that huge: it is a real mini junior suite. one good point is the bed quality. But O my God, it is so dirty: old bretzels on the floor, hairs in the bathroom, dust everywhere. And forget slippers, fresh flowers, new bathrobe (mine was certainly 1000 times used). An adaptor for European plugs? Sorry, we do not have will be the answer half a day later and files lost on your computer... The club lounge? Ouch! What a crime to good taste! After false Louis XIV, welcome to...nothing. A new dreadfull mixture of huge Roman modern antiques (that Cesar bust was the kind redneck will enthusiastically put in front of his house at retirement), low quality 70s, pseudo African safari seats... The funny thing is to compare this with interiors pictures in the displayed magazines. Food served is the one you sometimes cannot forget as it is not always fresh (grapefruit juice tastes the 3 day-old bitterness). And no waiter for 30 minutes while the breakfast buffet is almost empty: she was speaking with colleagues in their area. And do not try to ask for them: they will not hear you! The pool: here is the worst. Forget this ridiculous anti-decoration. Focus on matresses (old, dirty and wet), floor (wet, smelly and... between white, red and organic green), water (it is salt but it is smelly as well). The jacuzzi: even do not invite your enemy to enter it; you would be accused of crime after his bacterial attacks (I do not mention the old egg smell in the jacuzzi environment). Staff? Do you really need anybody when on a pool area? How spoiled children are you! If you cannot find the towels, well, go and buy one! Isn't that obvious in a 5 stars hotel? A good point for the barman, one of the few to try to do something 5 stars rated in the hotel. Others to be mentionned: I will not mention them but give them an advice: ESCAPE.... And they know that! Funny: the lounge area in the lobby is usually closed so that there is a total of 8 seats if you need to wait in the lobby!

Reviews.Title: “Overall, every nice”
Reviews.Author: Weary_Traveler_LA
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Windsor Court at the end of June. The website had a great deal and we upgraded to the Junior Suite on the Club Level because they were nearly half off. The room was spacious as was the marble bathroom but there was a peculiar, very floral smell in the sitting room which I attributed to the "antique" furniture. We had a decent city view and a tiny balcony on the 22nd floor. The room was whisper quiet after the nightly music died down about 10:30 PM. Where was this coming from? The club level included a nice breakfast spread which was sparsely attended Saturday morning but crowded on Sunday. They didn't clear dishes away or keep up with the food well when there was a crowd. The view from the club lounge was very nice overlooking the Mississippi river. They also had a nice tea service in the afternoon which I appreciated because I wouldn't have taken tea downstairs by myself. The gym was well equipped and barely used but stuffy. I also embarassingly got locked out of the club level on Sunday morning after my run because the key card gets deactivated being near a cell phone. (This is the first hotel I have ever had this encounter with). They cheerfully replaced it at the front desk while I stood there in sweaty gym clothes. The only problem I had with the valet occurred when I pulled up on Saturday just before 4 PM which is time for high tea. I asked them not to park the car far because we had dinner reservations at 6:30 PM. I knew they had a remote lot because I heard them apologizing to another guest that it would take at least 12 minutes to retrieve his car. Well, of course, we waited until almost 7 to get our car from that remote lot as well. Overall, the room was clean and nicely appointed. (We did have a 6 AM bathroom visitor -- a giant roach) and in post Katrina New Orleans I applaud the Windsor Court for continuing to try to deliver five star service.

Reviews.Title: “Getting better”
Reviews.Author: sebekdoxy
Reviews.Content: Ok, I mentioned in a previous review of another property that Windsor Court was one of the places that, although I have stayed there many times, I have never written a review of it. My most recent visit has changed my opinion from neutral to a real value. The club floor in now open. We booked a full suite on a holiday and paid a mere $305 including tax and service. The club floor suites are decent size and have been refurbished, however, the over abundance of Pottery Barn room accents were a little tacky. The new club floor lounge is very nice, quite large, if not a bit understaffed. That was understandable, the first time we went in there, we were the only people. The next time, there were about 15 people. I think that Windsor Court realized that they had to do something and I think that they did a commendable job. A few minuses- Our balcony was covered in cigarette butts from the previous guest. There was an 'UNO' card in the middle of the bedroom floor (kinda weird). The room wasn't all that clean. The club level indicates that you will have fresh flowers and personalized stationary in your room. Had neither, but no big deal The one small ancient TV had a satellite system that regularly lost its signal. The kitchen had a few useful items like glassware, but no silverware, cookware, plates or even a dishtowel. Had to call the front desk to find out the club lounge hours, there was no response from the club lounge phone. The bath/shower remains small for a property of this level. Although the club level offers its' own concierge and butler service, good luck finding their phone numbers. Some big improvements- Molten and Brown ammenities New Italian linens Freshly painted/papered rooms Service continues to improve. Food in the club quite nice. Having finally moved back to New Orleans last year (not sure how to change my profile), I can say that the Grand Dame is finally coming back. I think it worth a look, especially given the unbelievably low prices. I assure you, those prices will not last.

Reviews.Title: “Service with a Smile”
Reviews.Author: auburn8
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Windsor Court while back in New Orleans for a high school class reunion. Each and every employee I came in contact with at the Windsor Court was friendly and professional. The facilities are wonderful and are showing no ill effect from Katrina. I had a suite reserved until my family had to back out at the last minute so I downgraded to a deluxe room. The room was exceptionally large and very comfortable. The restroom was very large and marble tiled. The bed was outstanding as were the pillows. It would be nice for a 5* hotel to use fitted sheets on the bottom as the flat sheets refused to stay tucked in. Also, I'm not sure if the people in the room above me were loud walkers or there is not much sound insulation between floors. Those problems were minimal compared to the overall exceptional experience I had with the Windsor Court. As mentioned in several other reviews the location is outstanding, close to the Riverwalk, the Aquarium, Harrah's, the French Quarter, The Super Dome, and the Conference Center. I would highly recommend a stay in the Windsor Court.

Reviews.Title: “Great getaway”
Reviews.Author: texaslawman
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a good visit to New Orleans and a great visit to the Windsor Court. This is one of the best hotels in the City and almost back to normal from the Hurricane. While I noticed some old furnishings in the room, I could tell the staff went to great lengths to make sure everything was clean and orderly until everything could be replaced. Of course, there were some stains on the chairs in our room and some mold on the tub but I got over it. One thing that I could not get over is how some of the staff treated us at checkout. A couple of housekeepers and one front desk person in particular made our checkout experience upsetting. We were staying there as an American Express Platinum Card member which entitled us to a guaranteed 4 pm. checkout. Nonetheless, the housekeeping staff rang our door bell at least 3-4 times to ask when we were checking out and to ensure that it was soon. The worst was when the very front desk person who checked us in (and gave us the perks with our travel program) came to the room to see when we were checking out. I told him that we would be checking out at around 4. He told me that I would be charged if I stayed past 3!!! I reminded him about the program I was on and he looked surprised and walked away. I complained to the hotel manager who simply apologized and said that it would never happen again. Apparently, the checkout crew does not know when each guest checks out and assumes that everyone checks out at 11 or 12! Besides that (which could happen anywhere) we loved the hotel and our room. You will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at the Windsor Court”
Reviews.Author: LucyRoo
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Windsor Court for the second weekend of JazzFest, myself, husband and our two year old. The hotel staff were exceptionally friendly and helpful. We had a suite, most of the rooms are suites. It was large and comfortable with a small kitchenette - indispensable with a toddler. The bed was comfortable with nice sheets and down pillows. We had room service three times, it was the best room service food I have ever had. We also ate in the less formal Polo Club with our son, the staff were very accomodating and friendly. The pool is small, but very clean and well kept. The adjacent fitness room is well equipped with health club quality machines. I would definitely stay here again, the location is great and the service really is wonderful. Every single staff member was so helpful and friendly, without exception.

Reviews.Title: “One of the Best”
Reviews.Author: BrooklynNYC
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent the last weekend of April enjoying the city of New Orleans and going to Jazz Fest. There is nothing better than being at the festival all day and coming back to a hotel like the Windsor Court. It is first class all the way. Everyone from the doorman to the house maid treats like you a VIP. We asked the concierge on Friday night at 8pm to find us a good restaurant to eat in at 9pm. Within 10 minutes he had us a reservation at one of the better restaurants in town. Not an easy task during Jazz Fest weekend. We will return to this hotel and probably never stay anywhere else when in New Orleans.

Reviews.Title: “almost a five”
Reviews.Author: mileway
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 nights at this lovely hotel in New Orleans. It is really a hidden gem. The full suite was nice and roomy. They could have had 2 tvs - one for the bedroom, one for the sitting room. It is almost a five, just needs a little tweaking. Examples -- light out in the bathroom vanity light the whole time we were there. The service in the main restaurant was downright slow, and the service staff did not apoligize at all. But the Polo Lounge was great. We ended up eating lunch there one day and the service and food was fantastic. The hotel itself is beautiful. Ask for a room on the opposite of the casino. It can be loud at night. It is just on the outskirts of the French quarter, a walk of maybe 5 - 10 minutes to get to Bourbon Street.

Reviews.Title: “What a wonderful place”
Reviews.Author: GrahamB/RachelG
Reviews.Content: Service was outstanding, but not stuffy, always welcoming staff. We've lived in smaller places than the suite we stayed in. The decor was very well done. View of the Mississippi was very nice, particularly at night. Excellent food as well. Free wireless. Great location.

Reviews.Title: “To Still Post-Katrina service at pre-Katrina Prices”
Reviews.Author: phyllisraines
Reviews.Content: Sorry, the Club Level is still not orperating in January. I just returned from there yesterday, after booking the Club Level, only to be told that they were not "set Up" for the Club Level at this time, although I paid the price for three Club Level Rooms. Please don't expect anything better than the other levels, still a plastic shower curtain, worn bed linens, and large but not updated or luxury baths...........no hand towels in my room and the same old amentities, although I was told they were updated. Not true.......the Windsor needs to do some major changes to restore the hotel to it's former grandeur. It is so sad.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent service, room maintenance, everything- PERFECT!”
Reviews.Author: menace7
Reviews.Content: Want to know where to go for: 1) excellent service; 2) a facility that delivers what it promises; 3) staff personnel who appear to have a genuine ability and desire to be helpful; 4) clean rooms that clearly are attended to by housekeeping that cares; 5) local attractions and great restaurants; and 6) splendid day and evening views of the mighty Mississippi River? It's called the Windsor Court Hotel owned and operated by Orient Express Hotels. We simply got tired of throwing our money away on over priced make believe luxury resorts like some of the Ritz Carlton. Instead- this place delivers! If you'd like more, just drop me an e-mail and I'll reply. While you're there be sure and book at Antoine's and order the pan friend trout. Excellent, consistent and professional- that's how this place ranks.

Reviews.Title: “Nice stay but needs work”
Reviews.Author: busenkb
Reviews.Content: My husband and I , New Orleans natives, stayed at the Windsor for our Anniversary weekend. We had stayed here 5 years previously for part of our honeymoon. Being Katrina victims ourselves, we had moderate expectations for this hotel now past the 1 year anniversary of that fateful day. And that is about what we got. The hotel is still beautiful but is a little worn. The rooms could use a refurbishing. The carpet has stains and the furniture is somewhat beat up. We stayed in a suite and had great views of the river. We booked it for $199 through the hotel web site. A great price for the Windsor in its current condition. I wouldn't pay more and I am sure we didn't pay this 5 years ago. There is only continental breakfast for room service and at $18 is way overpriced for toast, a biscuit and a crossiant with cofffee and OJ. And that is not including tax and service charge. You would do much better getting out for breakfast (and all your meals for that matter-this is New Orleans!). Lunch and dinner room service is only on the weekends. We did not eat in the Grill Room (the hotel restaurant). As for the rest of the service, it seemed understaffed but everyone was pleasant and glad we were there. Housekeeping was late everyday. No clean room until 3-5 pm. Getting our car always took a while with only 2 guys working valet. Overall, I am glad we stayed here but mostly for the memories. Both my husband and I inquired about possible renovations to this hotel and they are underway and working down the floors. Hopefully the Windor will return to its original prestigous status. I am sure that we will try it out again but not until this is done.

Reviews.Title: “An experience never to be forgotten!!”
Reviews.Author: slrohrbaugh
Reviews.Content: I must say that in all my travels, I have never been treated so kindly from the time I arrived, until the time I left which was 5 days. The staff was amazing for it being the one year anniversary of Katrina and so many guests staying there throughout the week. My room was very comfortable, and the bathroom very spacious to include all ammenities, as I am a big guy who enjoys a bath now and then. The Valet staff were extraordinary especially David who worked hard to make all around him feel special. Room Service food was amazing and the bartender in the Polo Lounge can make a killer Rasberry Martini! I hope if I ever get a chance to visit New Orleans again, my company will choose the Windsor Court as our home away from home.

Reviews.Title: “Treated like royalty at the Windsor Court”
Reviews.Author: sbenedi
Reviews.Content: We returned to the Windsor Court Hotel for a vacation. We had stayed there prior to Katrina, and was not sure what to expect on our return visit. I am pleased to say that we had a wonderful stay. The staff is what makes this such a special place to stay. Robert Lowe is now the concierge, and he is a gem. Everyone, from the doorman, to the bellman, to the maid, to the front desk, went out of their way to make our stay special. It is true that room service for breakfast is limited to a continental breakfast, but, oh what a delight that was. We ordered breakfast for one(your choice of 4 pastries), with coffee set up for 2. Fresh buttery croissants that crackled when you pulled them apart, a fresh raspberry Danish with raspberries the size of strawberries, everything was yummy! Breakfast was delivered promply in about 10 minutes, and the tray was picked up about an hour later. This is not what I consider a family hotel. There were no children in the pool, the atmosphere was quiet and relaxed.

Reviews.Title: “Still post-Katrina service at pre-Katrina prices”
Reviews.Author: Westonian
Reviews.Content: We spent five days in a suite booked on the hotel website at $450 per day plus 13% tax. Having stayed in a suite at this hotel before, we discovered that the corner suites (1717, for example) are much larger than those elsewhere on the floor, even though they are the same price. There is a large bathroom, albeit with a plastic shower curtain in the tub instead of a separate shower, and a dressing room which includes another sink. The bedroom is a good size, although the bed is exceptionally uncomfortable and the bed linens are old and of poor quality. The living room is large, and has two sofas and an armchair around a coffee table, as well as a small dining table with two chairs; but there are only glass French doors separating it from the bedroom. There is a good-sized kitchen with a full-size refrigerator and a sink. A call to room service yielded a coffee maker along with the requisite cups, etc., for two people. The overall condition of the furnishings was acceptable, everything looking a bit dated but also clean and free of nicks, scratches and stains. High-speed Internet is free. The A/C has two zones and is reasonably quiet. The TVs, which incorporate a VCR, are ancient CRT boxes. There is a free library of videotaped movies downstairs. It was fun trying to remember how to use a VCR. Valet parking and check-out were friendly and efficient. However some other services are still in post-Katrina mode, which seems unnecessary nearly one year after the event. For example, the Front Desk agreed to gave the NYT delivered to our room every morning, but when I called to enquire about its whereabouts at 0630, I was told that the person who does that does not come on until 0700. (Although, curiously enough, the local paper was delivered to every room during the night.) There is still no concierge. Room service is still on a post-Katrina limited (type-written) menu, and it shuts down at 2300. Dinner was delivered promptly, but the table was not removed in response to our request. I put it in the corridor, and it was still there at 10 the next morning (quite smelly by that time). Breakfast is still buffet only, and a rip-off at $21 plus $3.50 for coffee (the first time I've paid extra for coffee with a buffet breakfast) plus 13% tax and no option of a continental breakfast at lower costs. When I questioned the bill on this last point, having consumed just two tiny muffins and a pat of butter, a suited Food and Beverage Manager showed up and refused to make any adjustment. In talking with the Director of Rooms who called to apologise about the two locust-sized insects which we found in our bedroom on the first night (one actually in the bed), we learned that floors 18-22 are being renovated and converted into a Club Level. The target date for completion of this work is mid-September. I understand that these room will have a flat-panel TV and, who knows, maybe even a proper shower.

Reviews.Title: “The Best Hotel In the City”
Reviews.Author: sweetgirlSt_Louis
Reviews.Content: I have just returned from my fourth visit to New Orleans and my third stay at the Windsor Court since Hurricane Katrina and I would not stay anywhere else in the City. Because my husband is a native of New Orleans, we have been traveling back to that City for over 25 years, During those years we have stayed at the big box hotels, small B&Bs Garden District Hotels and many in the French Quarter. In recent years because we owned a home on the Mississippi coast, hotels in New Orleans were not an issue for us. With the wrath of Katrina so went our vacation home and when we decided to make our first trip after the hurricane at Thanksgiving, the Windsor Court was one of the few hotels open. The warm welcome we received then as well as on our subsequent visits has truly made the Windsor Court our home away from home. Although we have booked our rooms at the cheapest rate, we have always been upgraded to a junior or full suite. The rooms are spacious, comfortable and most of all quiet. The staff has always gone out of their way to help us in any way - including making our 10 and ll year old children feel special and welcome. The restaurant and bar are absolutely wonderful and there is fresh coffee on the 2nd floor each morning at 6:30 to enjoy with your complimentary newspaper. From the moment you pull into the courtyard, every member of the staff is at your beck and call. It is wonderful to see the same faces and receive a "welcome back" from Jackie or Robert at the front desk. Everything is done in a highly professional manner. As an added bonus, the hotel is directly across the street from Restaurant August which is run by John Besh, one of the most highly regarded chefs in New Orleans who is also a hero to those workers that he cooks for on a volunteer basis. And in a city that struggles on a day to day basis to survive in so many ways, the Windsor Court is an oasis of elegance and calm. While you are there, eating at the restaurant, having cocktails in the bar, high tea in the afternoon or lounging at the wonderful pool, you can almost forget that you are in the midst of an ongoing disaster. Because the Windsor Court is in the Central Business District, it is not the hotel for anyone whose purpose in visiting is Bourbon Street or the French Quarter, although it is an easy walk across Canal Street to get there. But if you are looking for calm and quiet atmosphere with good service, the Windsor Court is the place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Above Average- Not Great”
Reviews.Author: JIMCHI
Reviews.Content: We stayed here last week for 4 days, our first visit to the hotel, but our 4th visit to New Orleans. We stayed in a full suite. which the hotel was offering at a deeply discounted rate. The suite on the 16th floor was very good sized and consisted of a living room and bedroom separated by French doors. There was also a butler's pantry which had a full refrigerator and an oven. The majority of the refrigerator consisted of a mini-bar. The suite was very quiet and had a nice view of the Mississippi River, although Harrah's Casino blocked part of the view. There were some housekeeping issues- they failed to give us any washcloths on the 2nd day of our stay; had to call and it took about 30 minutes to get them. One of the chairs in the living room had badly soiled arms and there was a stain on the carpet. We were surprised that despite having a butler's pantry/kitchen, there was no coffee maker in the suite. The Windsor Court does not have the best location for visiting the French Quarter. It seemed like every place of interest was about 8 blocks and a 20 minute walk away. Jackson Square is about a 10 minute walk. Despite these minor issues, we would consider staying there again on our next visit to New Orleans, although I don't think we would ever consider paying the full rack rate.

Reviews.Title: “Not a 5 Star! But go to New Orleans, anyway!”
Reviews.Author: Alice
Reviews.Content: I was not sure about going to New Orleans for my business conference but I had a nice time and was happy to spend my much appreciated tourist money. The streets are not flooded and my allergies did not act up. It is not as crowded and the shop keepers and restaurants are thrilled to see you and your wallets! Go to New Orleans before it gets crowded again with tourists! I stayed at the Windsor Court in March 2006 for a conference. I had a rate of $200 for a suite. The detailed review below on April 18, 2006 is very accurate. The hotel needs updating. It is not awful but not up to Orient Express impeccable quality. The first suite I was offered I declined (#616). A huge stain on the carpet and on the bedspreads. I went downstairs and the front desk gave me #1612. This room was much better and on a high floor. The wear and tear on the room was due to years of guests not Katrina. Nicked furniture, the finial came off the bedpost, old style televison sets. One TV did not work. Older bathroom fixtures, stained wallpaper, paint ready to peel in the bathroom and frayed upholstery. The deadbolt lock on the door did not work. Housekeeping promptly sent up a repairperson. There were some housekeeping missteps but I cut the hotel slack due to understaffing. No breakfast service. They should set up coffee urns in the lobby. The kitchenette had sticky counters and floors and old appliances. The Ritz Carlton is closed so no real competition. I would stay at WC again until no other game in town but I would not pay over $200. This is not up to Orient Express standards. New Orleans is back on its feet. I did go on a tour of the massively devasted suburbs. Worse than you can imagine. You won't see this damage if you come from the airport to the French Quarter or Garden district. The Saks is closed and some other stores but many opening up again. I was happy to do my part and spend my tourist dollars in NOLA.

Reviews.Title: “A Faded 5 Star”
Reviews.Author: Mirval
Reviews.Content: My most recent stay at the Windsor Court was reduced from a planned five night stay to one night. As an ex New Orleanian I am very familiar with most of the city's hotels. One night was enough to quickly gather that this wonderful hotel has many problems and is riding on it's famed reputation for service and luxury. I had reserved a "full suite" for $275 per night on a promotional rate on the Orient Express hotels website. I was assigned a large corner suite as requested. I have been an occassional guest of the Windsor Court for 15 years now. This was one of the finest hotels in the world; up until about 10 years ago this hotel shined like a diamond and was impeccably flawless in every way. It was slowly declining and now due to Hurricane Katrina and the resultant lack of staff, it's decline in service and ambience is horrible. The hotel is approximately 20 years old and is really starting to show it's age. The rooms and public areas need a serious remodel. The lovely art collection and classic British design will always remain but it's getting tired and everything needs a good scrub or replaced. Hurricane Katrina has resulted in the hotel being severely understaffed. The Windsor Court only has 30% of it's normal staffing levels "including contract housekeepers" according to the front desk clerk. Service was therefore dismal. The problems: a.) Housekeeping is very slack. My suite, 1501, had a 20 year old fridge with mold and mildew stains on the inside of the door. The top of the fridge and range hood were filthy and had not been cleaned since before Hurricane Katrina (8 months ago). b.) No turn down service (due to no staff). c.) Housekeeping was generally poor. Dusty room, stickers on the windows from October (glass was replaced due to hurricane blowing out the windows - housekeeping in 7 months had never bothered to remove the stickers from the new glass windows). d.) Room service is very limited (soups, sandwiches and simpler items) from 11 AM to 11 PM with a small menu. My lunch ordered at 1 PM was obviously previously prepared. The room service tray sat in the suite for 24 hours until I checked out. No one came to remove the tray. e.) No wi-fi internet in room. This is unacceptable for a hotel of the Windsor Court's famed stature. f.) Rooms with videocassette players. Not a DVD player in sight. Time to upgrade to Plasma flatscreens. g.) Horrible fabrics with clashing patterns (stripes on one sofa and brocade on the other) and loud floral prints on the curtains. Stripes, floral prints and patterned carpets create a hideous jungle of clashing fabrics. Very poor interior design. The Windsor Court needs a serious interior designer to keep the British "country home" a la Laura Ashley or Ralph Lauren feel. A luxury hotel needs to feel and look the part. h.) Worn out furniture. Nicked and abused. Quality furnishings that are now 20 years old and needing refinished. i.) Beds that are very ordinary. With even the Sheraton having a luxury bed with duvet cover, it's now time for the Windsor Court to deliver a luxury sleeping experience. Overall, this is still a lovely hotel. It is no longer 5 star. With a modernization program, serious renovation and more staff, it will easily once again become the premier grande dame of the city. Meanwhile, once the Ritz Carlton New Orleans reopens, it is a far superior property. Until the Ritz Carlton reopens I'm afraid New Orleans is without a 5 star hotel.

Reviews.Title: “same but so many fewer people”
Reviews.Author: kimhoney
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Windsor Court this past weekend. Our first trip to N.O. since Katrina and Rita. The hotel looks the same, rooms look the same, just a wonderful luxury hotel. But it's not nearly at 100% but how could it be with only 20% of its staff (which is not unusual city wide, in restaurants, stores, hotels)? The polo lounge bar is open more limited hours. It looks like tea was in full force. Little things like no robes, no chocolates at turn down (the absolutely unnecessary things that make the place so special). The staff that were there were superb. They all have survived especially traumatic times personally and professionally. Ask them about it. It seemed therapeutic to talk to waiters, bartenders, just everyone about the catastrophe. It really seems like most everyone down there is in a state of depression, with good reason as the area is still completely devastated. Of course the quarter is as it always was. Boisterous. All the restaurants were open and good, with somewhat limited menus and hours. We ate at GWFins, NOLA, Palace Cafe and August and all were excellent. We heard that uptown Commanders will open in July. No telling about DelMonico. Overall our visit was quite nice. We are so glad that our favorite city and our favorite hotel is making progress. Every visitor should, however, see history: Lakeview, Chalmette and the 9th Ward. Television does depict the massive nature of the destruction.

Reviews.Title: “Windsor Court - the best in town”
Reviews.Author: dre51
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Windsor Court for Valentine's Day in 2005 and thought we'd make it an annual event. We were a little hesitant as to whether everything would be the same, since the hurricane, but were delighted that the service was exactly as nice as it had been in '05. Infact, the staff seemed to go out of their way to welcome us back and provided detailed information on which restaurants were open and within walking distance. The place was packed, but the service was excellent.

Reviews.Title: “ok, preferred the ritz carlton”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Was nice enough, though expected more for the money.

Reviews.Title: “City welcomed us back!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Windsor Court last week to get away for one night for my birthday. This was our first trip to New Orleans since the hurricane. We have stayed here before, and were not sure what to expect. The front courtyard is as beautiful as we remember it, with no sign of damage. The hotel was beautifully decorated for Christmas. Our junior suite was well appointed, and looking at the view of the city from the balcony, one would never know what transpired here 3 months ago. The only reasons I have given the hotel 4 stars instead of 5 is that their famed restaurant, The Grill Room, is currently serving a buffet instead of a la carte. Also, room service is not available at this time. I asked the bellman about that, and he said they are waiting for more people to start coming to open up the full menu. We had dinner across the street at Cafe Adelaide where I have to say we had a delicious meal with a knowledgable, attentive wait staff. Cafe Adelaide is one of the Brennan family restaurants. We had wondered if quality staff would be available after the relocation of so many of the locals. During the day, we enjoyed antique shopping on Magazine street (surprisingly busy). Overall, my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our overnight stay. One other note: Approximately 60% of New Orleans hotel rooms are back on line. This website still says "Closed due to Hurricane Katrina" for most New Orleans hotels, but I would advise you to call your favorite hotel anyway to check. The front desk at the Windsor Court was surprised when I told them about the notice on tripadvisor. I noticed before typing this that it no longer says that when you click on Windsor Court.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Fantastic Service”
Reviews.Author: ecgp
Reviews.Content: This is a very pretty hotel. It is just beside Harrahs and not far at all from the quarter. We usually stay in the FQ when visiting New Orleans but our trip was planned last minute and this was the best available. Most of the rooms have balconies. We stayed in a one bedroom suite which had a separate bedroom, small kitchen, living room and two balconies. The concierge, bellmen and front desk staff were all very polite. Room service was expensive, but no more than any other New Orleans hotel and very quick. We did not eat in the restaurants -- they require a jacket for service and we did not bring "dressy" clothes. I would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Over-Rated and Tired”
Reviews.Author: nocello
Reviews.Content: Off in the middle of nowhere behind the casino was the location for this tired, pretty but messy hotel. Staff was rude and slow to serve. Food in the grill room was laughably overpriced and full of pretense. It's time for a facelift for this one. Good thing the Ritz is in town for luxury and exceptional service. As someone who travels to New Orleans twice a month, this isn't worth the money.

Reviews.Title: “Fair - Go elsewhere for the money”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Management not very helpful when theft occured.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel stay ever!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We were welcomed at the front door by handsome, friendly doormen. Our luggage was whisked away. We sat at a table! to check in. We had arrived early, without warning the staff, but they offered to call us on the cell when the room was available, which was within a half-hour of arriving. They have a marvelous saftety-deposit box system - you get to keep one key, the hotel keeps the other and you have a private box. One point for those planning on staying here - the location is 3 blocks off the quarter - but it is blessedly quiet and not a bad walk at all. The room (suite) was very clean and markedly free of tacky furniture/art. It had a whole kitchenette, including a full refrigerator, stove and oven. The toiletries were below average, but who cares? The very best thing was the pool. It is on the secluded roof of the 4th floor. You come out and the pool man greets you by name. He then places a cover on the upholstered lawnchair you select. He will bring you a cocktail if you ask and a glass of water with a piece of orange in it if you don't. He will bring you a towel, an ashtray, heck, I think he'd bring anything! There is something wonderful about the pool arrangement, too - nice plants and urns scattered here and there. We also had room service (which was just beyond average but at least timely) and dinner at the restaurant (New Orleans Grill). One of the best meals I have ever had! Truly, the hotel and its physical attributes are among the best but really puts this place on top is the staff. They make you feel like you are a STAR! There is no prissiness or even a hint of pretension. I will never stay anywhere else in New Orleans. Other than the toiletries, the only thing I would change is to put a nice spa in the premises - one with plenty of cool water features and some nifty treatments.
